section.name: name
section.description: hc - an HCLI for interacting with a CNC via GRBL Controller (e.g. an OpenBuilds BlackBox controller) via input and output streams

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc <command>

section.name: description
section.description:
The "hc" HCLI allows you to control a CNC through the command line (e.g. OpenBuilds C-Beam Machine) via the GRBL protocol, and acts as an interface for your CNC (e.g. OpenBuilds Interface CNC Touch) to stream gcode, to home, or to jog your CNC. You can send control commands and gcode commands as an input stream, and the hc service will respond accordingly.

This HCLI relies on the use of a serial port to a GRBL compliant controller. You can scan to find out which serial device you can send gcode streams to.

This HCLI handles sequencing of queued jobs properly (i.e. hc -j 'jobname' by waiting for the GRBL to report being idle before picking up the next job in the queue. This allows for job sequences to be an admixture of gcode and commands such as feed hold '!' or status '?', which wouldn't normally be intermixed with gcode files. This feature, coupled with HCLI's native capabilities allows for complex scripted or coded automated job sequences.

Note that the hc CNC HCLI doesn't queue jobs properly for sequential streaming execution in a multiprocess context (e.g. multiple workers under gunicorn). Please configure the environment such that the HCLI runs in a single process (e.g. --workers=1 under gunicorn). See "hcli_core help" for an example configuration for hc.

section.name: examples
section.description:
hc scan

hc connect

hc connect /dev/tty.usbserial-AR0JI0GV

echo '$$' | hc

cat test.gcode | hc

cat test.gcode | hc -j 'test job'

command.name: scan
command.description: The "scan" command scans and lists connected serial devices.

command.name: reset
command.description: The "reset" command stops the CNC by sending the soft reset ctrl-x command to the GRBL controller.

command.name: status
command.description: The "status" command returns the current status of the GRBL controller by sending the ? command.

command.name: stop
command.description: The "stop" command pauses the CNC by sending the ! command to the GRBL controller (feed hold).

command.name: resume
command.description: The "resume" command resumes the CNC by sending the ~ command to the GRBL controller (cycle start).

command.name: connect
command.description: The "connect" command connects to the GRBL controller via serial port by attempting to wake it up.

command.name: home
command.description: The "home" command is used to home the CNC by sending the '$H' signal.

command.name: unlock
command.description: The "unlock" command is used to kill an alarm lock by sending the '$X' signal.

command.name: jobs
command.description: The "jobs" command lists all queued jobs.

command.name: jog
command.description: The "jog" command allows for real-time continuous jogging via the arrow keys.

command.name: zero
command.description: The "zero" command sends commands to help zero the CNC to working coordinates 0, 0, 0 for x, y, or z.

command.name: logs
command.description: The "logs" command allows for a client to poll for a log tail against the hc service log output stream.

command.name: setzero
command.description: The "setzero" command is used to setup the (G54 Coordinates) to zero for, x, y, or z.

command.name: disconnect
command.description: The "disconnect" command disconnects from the GRBL controller, which also interrupts any ongoing operation.

option.name: -j
option.description: The "-j" option is used to help supply a friendly job name to indicate job purpose and sequencing.

section.name: name
section.description: scan - scan for avaiable serial ports to stream gcode to.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc scan

section.name: description
section.description: The "scan" lists available serial devices that could be used to stream control and gcode commands to.

section.name: name
section.description: reset - sends the soft reset ctrl-x signal (0x18) to the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc stop

section.name: description
section.description: The "reset" command sends the ctrl-x signal (0x18) to the GRBL controller. This immediately halts and safely soft resets Grbl without a power-cycle. The immediate queue, job queue and serial buffers are also cleared to avoid subsequent commands executing unexpectedly.

section.name: name
section.description: status - sends the ctrl-x signal (0x18) to the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc stop

section.name: description
section.description: The "status" command sends the status signal (?) to the GRBL controller.

section.name: name
section.description: stop - sends the feed hold signal (!) to the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc stop

section.name: description
section.description: The "stop" command sends the feed hold signal (!) to the GRBL controller to pause motion.

section.name: name
section.description: resume - sends the cycle start signal (~) to the GRBL controller to resume motion.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc resume

section.name: description
section.description: The "resume" command sends the cycle start signal (~) to the GRBL controller to resume motion.

section.name: name
section.description: connect - connects to the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc connect <serialport>

section.name: description
section.description: The "connect" command connects to the GRBL controller via a serial port provided as an optional parameter. Without the optional serialport parameter, hc scans for all available serial ports and tries to connect to each in sequence until it finds a GRBL controller. This may be disruptive to serial devices in certain cases or may connect to the wrong GRBL controller if more than one is connected via serial port. If disruptive, impractical, incorrect, or if you prefer to avoid risks, favor providing the correct serial port directly as a parameter by first listing available serial ports via "hc scan".

section.name: examples
section.description: hc connect\n\nhc connect /dev/tty.usbserial-AR0JI0GV

section.name: name
section.description: jog - jogs the CNC via the $J signal to the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc jog

section.name: description
section.description:
The "jog" command accepts a continuous input stream of arrow key bytes, or other bytes, from the terminal and sends corresponding jog commands to the GRBL controller to get a real-time like jogging response from a CNC.

Note that the terminal has to send bytes fast enough for jogging to respond correctly. If you are experiencing stuttering problems with continuous jogging, increase the repeat rate and initial delay of keystrokes in your terminal.

"esc" unlock the jogger.

"left" x-.

"right" x+.

"up" y+.

"down" y-.

";" z+.

"/" z-.

"-" reduces the feed rate by 250.

"=" increases the feed rate by 250.

"[" reduces the unit scaling by a factor of 10.

"]" increases the unit scaling by a factor of 10.

"s" output jogger status.

"u" toggles the unit; imperial (default) or metric.

"i" sets incremental mode.

"c" sets continuous mode (default)

section.name: example
section.description:
hc jog | bash &>/dev/null

trap 'stty sane' SIGINT; stty -icanon -echo; while input=$(dd bs=20 count=1 2>/dev/null); do echo "$input" | hc jog; done

section.name: name
section.description: unlock - unlocks the GRBL controller after an alarm is raised.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc home

section.name: description
section.description: The "unlock" command is used to kill an alarm lock by sending the '$X' signal.

section.name: name
section.description: zero - tells the GRBL to go to work coordinates 0, 0, 0 for x, y, or z.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc zero [x | y | z | xy | xz | yz | xyz]

section.name: description
section.description: The "zero" command sends commands to help zero the CNC to working coordinates 0, 0, 0 for x, y, or z. If x, y, or z are omitted, the CNC is sent to 0, 0, 0 for all axes (x and y first, zero last).

section.name: example
section.description:
hc zero x

hc zero yz

hc zero

section.name: name
section.description: logs - tails hc service logs.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc logs

section.name: description
section.description: The "logs" command allows for a client to poll for a log tail against the hc service log output stream.

section.name: examples
section.description: while true; do hc logs; sleep 0.01; done

section.name: name
section.description: setzero - tells the GRBL controller to set the work offset to zero relative to machine coordinates (G54) for x, y, or z.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc setzero <x | y | z | xy | xz | yz | xyz>

section.name: description
section.description: The "setzero" command is used to setup the (G54 Coordinates) to zero for, x, y, or z.

section.name: example
section.description:
hc setzero x

hc setzero xz

hc setzero xyz

section.name: name
section.description: disconnect - disconnects from the GRBL controller.

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc disconnect

section.name: description
section.description: The "disconnect" command disconnects from the GRBL controller.

section.name: name
section.description: xyz - sets zero for x, y, and z (G54 coordinates).

section.name: synopsis
section.description: hc setzero xyz

section.name: description
section.description: The "xyz" command sets zero for x, y, and z on the work offset relative to machine coordinates (G54).
